content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–2, use the following passage:

A runner is training for a marathon. She runs more than 4 days each week. Each day, she runs between 12 and 15 miles. The marathon is 3 months away at the most.

1. What does the inequality \(d > 4\) represent?

Correct! the number of days the runner runs each week

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the number of days the runner runs each week. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. What does the inequality \(12\;\leq\;m\;\leq\;15\) represent?

Correct! the number of miles the runner runs each day

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the number of miles the runner runs each day. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 3-8, write an inequality to represent the constraint given.


3. There are less than 4 patients, p, in the waiting room.

Correct! \(p\;<\;4\;\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(p\;<\;4\;\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. There are no more than 6 cats, c, in the yard.

Correct! \( c ≤ 6 \)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(c≤6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. There are no less than 7 markers, m, in the drawer.

Correct! \(m\;\geq\;7\;\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(m\;\geq\;7\;\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. The basket has between 12 and 19 eggs, e.

Correct! \(12 < e < 19 \)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(12 < e < 19\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. The total sales of tickets to a show is more than $68. An adult ticket, a, costs $8 and a children’s ticket, c, is $3.

Correct! \(8a + 3c > 68 \)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(8a + 3c > 68\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. There needs to be at least 1 pound of clay, c, for every 4 students, s.

Correct! \(c\;\geq\;\frac s4\;\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(p\;\geq\;\frac s4\;\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 9-11, use the following passage:

A doctor sees between 7 and 12 patients each day. On Mondays and Tuesdays, the appointment times are 15 minutes. On Wednesdays and Thursdays, they are 30 minutes long. On Fridays, they are one hour long. The doctor works for no more than 8 hours a day. Here are some inequalities that represent this situation.

\(0.25\;\leq\;y\;\leq\;1\)            \(7\;\leq\;x\;\leq\;12\)           \(xy\;\leq\;8\)

9. What does the variable x represent?

Correct! the number of patients the doctor sees each day

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the number of patients the doctor sees each day. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. What does the variable x represent?

Correct! the part of an hour that each appointment lasts

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the part of an hour that each appointment lasts. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

11. What does the expression \(xy\) in the last inequality mean in this situation?

Correct! the total time the doctor spends working with patients each day

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the total time the doctor spends working with patients each day. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 12-14, use the following passage:

Arnav wants to build a dog house. He makes a list of the materials needed:

  • At least 60 square feet of plywood for the surfaces
  • At least 36 feet of wood planks for the frame of the dog house
  • Between 1 and 2 quarts of paint

Arnav's budget is $65. Plywood costs $0.70 per square foot, planks of wood cost $0.10 per foot, and paint costs $8 per quart.


12. Which inequality represents the square feet of plywood needed?

Correct! \(p\;\geq\;60\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(p\;\geq\;60\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

13. Which inequality represents the number of wood planks needed?

Correct! \(w\;\geq\;36\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(w\;\geq\;36\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

14. Which inequality represents the number of quarts of paint needed?

Correct! \(1\;\leq\;q\;\leq\;2\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(1\;\leq\;q\;\leq\;2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
